turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: You don't talk very much.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: I ain't ever talked to a movie star before.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I ain't no movie star. I'm just in high school.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Oh no? I thought you was a movie star.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: You go first. Let me watch how to do this.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You don't get nothin' done by watchin'. You just gotta do it. Here, I'll help you.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: That's it. Just grip up a little tighter. That's it. You're gonna be real good at this. How does that feel?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: It feels real good.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Just keep your eye on the ball.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Should I hit it?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Just give it a nice little tap.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I can't find my ball.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Can you see it?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Can you see it?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: What does that mean?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Jake, this is your father's bedroom.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: That's all right. He don't mind.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Jake...

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: It's OK.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Are you sure we should be doing this?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Come over here.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: You said never to touch you before a fight.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: If you let me do it, I'll murder you. Come here.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: You said I couldn't. You've been good for two weeks...

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Come here.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Take off my pants.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Jake...

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Do what I say.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Now take the rest off.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Jake, you made me promise not to get you excited.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Go 'head. Do it.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I like the gym smell.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Now take your panties off.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Now, touch me...  ...here.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Oh, Jake.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Joey's right. Janiro's up-and coming, he's good looking...

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What do you mean, "good looking?"

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Well, he's popular. A lotta people like Janiro. You beat him and it only figures they'll wanna see you get a title shot. But, what do I know? I should keep my mouth shut, I should...

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Who asked you?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: But, Jake, I was just...

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Who asked you?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I was just...

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Who asked you?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What're you lookin' at? You lookin' at him?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: No, I'm not. I'm looking at you.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Don't tell me "No." I saw you lookin' at him. Why, you like him?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I'm not interested in him.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You're not interested in him?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: No, I'm not.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: In other words, you're not interested in him but you'd be interested in somebody else, right?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Jake, c'mon now. Don't start.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Look at this, all of a sudden everybody's a fuckin' Romeo around here. Did you see the way she was lookin' at him?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Vickie?... Vickie, you asleep?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You asleep?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Yeah, what?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Tell me, you think of anybody else when I'm making love to you?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Nobody. I love you, remember?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Then why'd you say that thing about Tony Janiro?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: What did I say?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: That he's got a pretty face.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I never noticed his face.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You sure you're not thinking of him right now?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Positive.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You're the one who said he was good looking. You think he's good looking 'cause I know you think he's good- looking. I'll smash his face inside out. I'll make him into dog meat. Nobody's gonna think he's good-looking when I get through with him. So you just go ahead and think about who you want.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Hey, you don't say goodbye to him like that.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: What did I do?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You don't kiss like that. Hello and goodbye, that's all you do.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: All I did...

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You know what I'm talking about. Don't ever make me look bad on the night of my big fight.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: You're hurting my arm.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: But Jake... I didn't say anything...

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Don't ever do that again. You don't  do it!

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Jake...

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Tryin' to get this fuckin' TV to work. Paid all this money for it and still can't get a station a mile away. And Mr. Wizard here ain't no help.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I went out.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What's that kissing on the mouth shit?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Where you been all day?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I took the kids to my sister's.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: I called. You weren't there.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I got bored so I went to the movies.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What'd you see?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I went to the movies.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What'd you see?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: "Father of the Bride."

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What was it about?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Oh, c'mon. For Christsake, do I have to tell you everything?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Did you ever go to the Copa when I was away?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: What're you talking about?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Answer me when I talk to you. What happened that night?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I am answering...

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What do I have to do to get a straight answer around here.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Jake, no --

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Do I have to kill you, eh?  Do I have to kill somebody to get an answer?  I know about you at the Copa. I know all about it.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I didn't do anything wrong. I swear. I just had a few drinks.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: With Salvy, eh?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I went with Sandy and Vera. Salvy was there.  Stop it. I just had a drink, that's all. I didn't do anything wrong.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Come out of there! Did you fuck Salvy?  Answer me. Open this fuckin' door, you fuckin' cunt!  Who've you been fuckin'?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Nobody, I tell you. Jake stop it.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You're a fuckin' liar.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I'll say anything you want me to say. I fuckled Salvy. I fucked Tommy. I fucked your brother. I fucked everybody! What do you want to hear? I sucked your brother's fuckin' cock!

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You did?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Yeah, I sucked his cock.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: You're killing him. You're killing him for nothing. Stop it.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Get the fuck outa here. Whadda you mean nothing'? You stupid bitch!

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Nothing is what I said! Go on, kill me.  Kill me.  I'm not afraid of you anymore. I don't care if you kill me like you're killing him. You're a sick animal.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: You're the fuckin' animal! You ran around with every guy I knew while I was breakin' my ass for you.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: You're not only an animal, you're a stupid animal.  You're rotten.  Rotten.  Rotten.  You're a sick maniac. A maniac! You belong in a mental hospital.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: You know, if there's one thing -- I just don't understand you, not one single little bit. You love me?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Yeah --

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Jake, why don't you just try lying down and get some rest.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: I don't know what it is. I dunno, it's the kind of thing that -- the words won't come out.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Jake --

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I want to say something to you without you blowing your stack.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: OK. Talk.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Why don't you just call him up?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What do I say to him? Call him up on the phone and say, "Joey, I'm sorry about that little trouble we had. How about havin' dinner?" Is that what I say?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: No, not that.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Then what?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: I miss Joey. I wish Joey was here.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Why don't you just call him?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: I dunno.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Tell him how you feel -- you miss him. Tell him you're sorry.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Ok, all right. Telephone's in the hall. Dial his number.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: I'm sorry. I had to work late last night. Slept at the club.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I'm leaving you Jake.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Sure, what else is new?

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: No. This time it's true. I didn't bother to tell you until I had everything worked out.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Open the door, Vickie.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: No. I won't talk to you where you can use your hands on me.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Aw, c'mon. Don't say that.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I got a lawyer, Jake. We're getting a divorce. I'm getting custody of the kids.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Aw, c'mon, Vick --

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I'm sick of it. I can't watch you this way. You're too drunk all the time. There's too many girls. I can't... I don't wanna talk about it. I made up my mind.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Vickie, open up. I need to come in.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Are you drunk?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: No. Open the door.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: The kids are sleeping.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: I promise I just gotta pick up one thing.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: All right, just don't make any noise.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: I need ten thousand dollars. My lawyer says if we can spread ten thousand bucks around, we can get the case dropped.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: But they don't have a case against you.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Are you kiddin'? Did you ever see a 14-year-old testify in court? Did you see the papers? "LaMotta on Vice Rap." Everybody likes a shot at the Champ.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Jake, be careful! What're you doing to the belt?!

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Don't make no difference no more.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Can't you get the money from your friends?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: What friends?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Hi, Tommy. How are you?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Jake, sit down for a minute.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Fuckin' kid! You're the best fuckin' fighter around. Loved what you did to Satterfield. Them "moulan yans" -- forget about it. They're all afraid to fight you.

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: C'mon, Tommy --

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: How you feelin'? Ok? You feelin' good?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Never felt better.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Tony Janiro's gotta watch out, eh?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: He should.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: This Janiro's a good fighter, pretty good-lookin' kid.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: How's the weight? Ok?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: Yeah, the weight's Ok.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: All right, lemme ask you something. Let's say I was a good friend of yours. And I was telling you I was gonna bet a lot of money on you in this Janiro fight. What would you tell me?

turns.speaker: JAKE
turns.text: I'd tell you to bet a bundle.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Salvy, would I steer you wrong? Let's say that's the truck; it's full of cigarettes, right? Now, two o'clock this morning we move the truck from here to there,  take the cigarettes out, sell 'em, make some cash.

turns.speaker: SALVY
turns.text: Hey but Joey, you're thinking nickels and dimes. The money's with your brother.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: What do you want from my life, Salvy? He's my brother.

turns.speaker: SALVY
turns.text: He ain't doin' the right thing. He's makin' beans compared to what he should be makin'. Can't you make him understand that?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Hey, leave the kids alone.

turns.speaker: SALVY
turns.text: Get lost.  Hey kids, "A cop is a rat." Remember that, "A rat."

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I can't convince him. He's got such a thick head, I'd like to crack it open myself. Believe me, my own brother. It's very hard. You don't have to convince me -- I know we should be with Tommy. You talk to him. He don't listen to nobody.

turns.speaker: SALVY
turns.text: Look, I'm just tellin' you how Tommy feels. Jake is makin' it hard on himself. Tommy wants him with us. It's as simple as that.

turns.speaker: SALVY
turns.text: Talk some sense into him, will ya? You're still his brother. If he ain't gonna listen to you, he ain't gonna listen to nobody!

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: All right, I'll try. See you later.

turns.speaker: SALVY
turns.text: Tomorrow, at the gym. Don't forget.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Right, the gym.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I said, let's go.

turns.speaker: SALVY
turns.text: Joey, relax. You're taking this the wrong way. Why don't you sit down and have a drink?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Excuse me, I'm talking to my sister in-law.

turns.speaker: SALVY
turns.text: Excuse me for living.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: What do you think, I'm blind? My brother's breaking his ass in a ring, and you're here with his wife.

turns.speaker: SALVY
turns.text: Hey Joey, I'm here with Patsy and Vera and Sandy. And Vickie just happened to come along. We're just trying to have a good time. What do you want from me? So, why don't you just take it easy before this gets out of hand.

turns.speaker: SALVY
turns.text: Hey Joey, whadda ya lookin' to die young?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I'll suck your eyes out! I'll fuckin' take the two of you.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: What're you doin' with Salvy? You shouldn't be here with him. Jake's away killin' himself. Suppose he found out.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: What the hell am I doing wrong? Just because Jake is training, I can't go out? What am I, a goddamn prisoner?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: No, you're his wife.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: I'm not doing anything wrong. I'm just trying to have a good time. Do I have to be cooped up in the house all the time?

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: It don't look right.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: Well, go ahead, tell Jake. He's gonna kill me anyway. It's a matter of time.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: I'm not gonna tell him nothing; but if he finds out, he will kill you. What's the matter with you? Aren't you happy? You got everything you want.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: You don't sleep with him. I do. I don't get to breathe without tellin' him. He keeps me in a cage. If he thinks I'm lookin' at somebody the wrong way, I get used as a punching bag. He don't trust nobody. If he saw the two of us talking together right now, you'd be in trouble too -- believe me. Look at me, Joey. I'm 19 years old. I wanna enjoy my life. I love Jake, but you don't know. He gets crazy sometimes. I'm scared.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: Try to understand, Vickie. Jake's got a lotta aggravation. He's been a top contender too long.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: That's right, take his part. You're his brother. He's never gonna be champ. Too many people are against him.

turns.speaker: JOEY
turns.text: And you're drinking with them right now.

turns.speaker: VICKIE
turns.text: And I'm gonna finish my drink. And, I'm gonna have a good time, because I ain't doing nothing wrong.

turns.speaker: BABY SITTER
turns.text: This is Doyle's house.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: This is L. B. Jefferies, a friend of Tom's. Who am I talking with?

turns.speaker: BABY SITTER
turns.text: This is the baby sitter.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Oh. When are they expected home?

turns.speaker: BABY SITTER
turns.text: I'm hired 'til one. They went to dinner and maybe night-clubbing.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well, if he calls in, tell him to get in touch with L. B. Jefferies right away. I might have quite a surprise for him.

turns.speaker: BABY SITTER
turns.text: Does he have your number, Mr. Jefferies?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: He has it. Thank you.

turns.speaker: BABY SITTER
turns.text: Goodnight.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Indo-China -- Jeff predicted it would go sky-high.

turns.speaker: BRYCE
turns.text: From the looks of Davidson's cable, it might even go higher than that. And we haven't even got a camera over there.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: This could go off in a month -- or an hour.

turns.speaker: BRYCE
turns.text: I'll pull somebody out of Japan.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Bryce, the only man for this job is sitting right here in town.  Get me L. B. Jefferies.

turns.speaker: BRYCE
turns.text: Jefferies?

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Name me a better photographer.

turns.speaker: BRYCE
turns.text: But his leg!

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Don't worry -- it comes off today.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: It was in her favorite handbag -- And, Mr. Doyle, that can lead to only one conclusion.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Namely?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Like disposing of their wives?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Get that idea out of your mind. It will only lead you in the wrong direction.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Of course, it's normal for a man to tie his trunk up with a heavy rope.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: When the lock is broken -- yes.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Mrs. -- Thorwald's -- clothes. -- Clean -- carefully packed -- not too stylish -- but presentable.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Didn't you take it to the crime lab?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I would say that is looked as if she wasn't coming back.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: That's what they call a family problem.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You didn't see the killing, or the body? How do you know there was a murder?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Because everything that man's done has been suspicious. Trips at night in the rain, saws, knives, trunks with rope, and a wife that isn't there any more.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I'll admit it all has a mysterious sound -- but is could mean a number of different things. Murder is the least likely.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Go ahead, Doyle -- tell me he's an unemployed magician -- amusing the neighborhood with sleight-of-hand.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: It's too stupid and obvious a way to murder -- in full view of fifty windows -- and then sit over there --  -- smoking a cigar -- waiting for the police to pick him up.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well, officer -- do your duty.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You've got a lot to lean about homicide, Jeff. Morons have committed murder so shrewdly that it took a hundred trained police minds to catch them. That salesman wouldn't just knock off his wife after dinner, toss her in a trunk and put her in storage.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I'll bet it's been done.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Almost everything's been done -- under panic. But this is a thousand to one shot. That man's still sitting around his apartment; he isn't panicked.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You think I made all this up?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I think you saw something -- that probably has a very simple explanation.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: For instance?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: His wife took a trip.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: She -- was -- an -- invalid!

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You told me.  I've got to run, Jeff.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: All right -- you don't believe me.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I -- uh -- won't report it to the Department. Let me poke into a little on my own. No point in you getting any ridiculous publicity.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: We know the wife is gone. I'll see if I can find out where.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Do that.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: By the way  what happened to your leg?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I was jaywalking.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: He has a six months lease, and has used up a little over five and a half months of it.  Quiet. Drinks, but not to drunkenness. Pays his bill promptly, with money earned as a consume jewelry salesman -- wholesale. Keeps to himself, and none of the neighbors got close to him, or his wife.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I think they missed their chance with her.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: She never left the apartment --

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Then where is she -- in the ice box?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: -- until yesterday morning.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: What time?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Six ayem.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I think that's about the time I fell asleep.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Too bad. The Thorwalds were just leaving the apartment house at that time.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Feel a little foolish?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Who said they left then?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Who left -- where?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: The Thorwalds -- at six in the morning?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: The building superintendent, and two tenants. Flat statements -- no hesitation. And they all jibed to the letter. The Thorwalds were leaving for the railroad station.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Now how could anybody guess that? They had, perhaps, signs on their luggage, "Grand Central Or Bust!"?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: The superintendent met Thorwald coming back. He said Thorwald told him he had just put his wife on the train for the country.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: A very convenient guy -- this superintendent. Have you checked his bank deposits lately?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Jeff -- huh?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well -- what good is his information?!! It's a second-hand version of an unsupported statement by the murderer himself -- Thorwald! Anybody actually see the wife get on the train?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I hate to remind you -- but this all started because you said she was murdered. Now did anyone, including you, actually see her murdered?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Doyle -- are you interested in solving a case, or making me look foolish?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: If possible -- both.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well then do a good job of it! Get over there, and search Thorwald's apartment! It must be knee-deep in evidence.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I can't do that.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I mean when he goes out for a paper, or a drink, or something. What he doesn't know won't hurt him.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I can't do it even if he's gone.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: What's the matter? Does he have a courtesy card from the police department?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Now don't get me mad! Even a detective can't walk in anybody's apartment and search it. If I were ever caught in there, I'd lose my badge inside of ten minutes!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Just make sure you're not caught. If you find something, you've got a murderer and nobody will care about a couple of house rules. If you find nothing -- he's clear.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: At the risk of sounding stuffy, Jeff -- I'll remind you of the Constitution, and the phrase "search warrant" issued by a judge who knows the Bill of Rights verbatim. He must ask for evidence.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Give him evidence.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I can hear myself starting out. "Your Honor -- I have a friend who's an amateur sleuth, an one night, after a heavy supper --"  He'd throw the New York State Penal Code right in my face. -- And it's six volumes.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: By morning there might not be anything left to find in his apartment.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: A detective's nightmare.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: What do you need before you can search -- bloody footsteps leading up to the door?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: One thing I don't need is heckling! You called and asked me for help -- and now you're acting like a taxpayer!

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: How did we ever stand each other in that same plane for three years?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You know, every day for three years I asked myself that same question?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Ever get an answer?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Yeah -- frequently -- it ran something like this: "Your request for transfer turned down --"

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Forget the story -- find the trunk. Mrs. Thorwald's in it!

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Oh -- I almost forgot!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Is -- is Anna -- who I think it is?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Mrs. Thorwald.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Enough to scare me that you wouldn't get here in time, and we'd lose him.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You think he's getting out of here?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Everything he owns is laid out on the bedroom, ready for packing.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Jewelry?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: He has his wife's jewelry hidden in among his clothes over there.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You sure it belongs to his wife?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That wasn't Mrs. Thorwald who left with him yesterday morning?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You figured that out, huh?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Did you ever own a saw?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well, in the garage, back home, we --

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: And how many people did you cut up with the couple of with it? Or hundred knives you've probably owned in your lifetime?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: But I'm not a killer!

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Your logic is backward.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: If I'd been careful piloting that reconnaissance plane, you wouldn't have taken the kind of pictures that got you a medal, a big job, fame, money --

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: All the things I hate.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Oh -- that phone call!  I gave them your number -- hope you don't mind.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That depends on who "they" were.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: The police Department at Merritsville. They called to report. The trunk was just picked up -- by Mrs. Anna Thorwald.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Jefferies.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: This is Doyle, Jeff.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Tom, I've got something real big for you.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Look Jeff, don't louse up my night with another man killer stuffing a grisly trunk that turns out to be --

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Listen to me! Lisa's been arrested.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Your Lisa?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: My Lisa. She went into Thorwald's apartment, and he came back. The only way I could get her out was to call the police.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: I told you that --

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I know what you told me! She went in to get evidence, and she came out with it.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Like Mrs. Thorwald's wedding ring. If that woman were still alive, she'd be wearing it.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: A possibility.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: A fact! Last night he killed a dog for pawing in his garden. Why? Because he had something buried in there. Something a dog could scent.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Like an old hambone?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I don't know what pet name Thorwald had for his wife. And that night he went out half a dozen times with the metal suitcase. He wasn't taking his possessions, because they're up in his apartment now!

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: You think perhaps it was "old hambone?"

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: In sections! And one other thing, doubting Tom -- it just occurred to me that all the calls Thorwald made were long distance! If he called his wife the day she left -- after she arrived in Merritsville -- why did she need to send him a postcard saying she'd arrived?

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Where'd they take Lisa?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Precinct Six. I sent a friend over with bail money.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: Maybe you won't need it. I'll run it down, Jeff.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Just don't dally. Thorwald knows he's being watched. He won't hang around long.

turns.speaker: DOYLE
turns.text: If that ring checks out, we'll give him an escort. So long.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Jefferies.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Congratulations, Jeff.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: For getting rid of that cast.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Who said I was getting rid of it?

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: This is Wednesday.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Gunnison -- how did you get to be such a big editor -- with such a small memory?

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Wrong day?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Wrong week. Next Wednesday I emerge from this plaster cocoon.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: That's too bad, Jeff. Well, I guess I can't be lucky every day. Forget I called.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Yeah. I sure feel sorry for you, Gunnison. Must be rough on you thinking of me wearing this cast another whole week.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Indo-China. Got a code tip from the bureau chief this morning. The place is about to go up in smoke.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Didn't I tell you! Didn't I tell you it was the next place to watch?

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: You did.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Okay. When do I leave? Half-hour? An hour?

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: With that cast on -- you don't.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Stop sounding stuffy. I'll take pictures from a jeep. From a water buffalo if necessary.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: You're too valuable to the magazine for us to play around with. I'll send Morgan or Lambert.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Swell. I get myself half-killed for you -- and you reward me by stealing my assignments.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: I didn't ask you to stand in the middle of that automobile race track.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You asked for something dramatically different! You got it!

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: So did you. Goodbye, Jeff.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: You've got to get me out of here! Six weeks -- sitting in a two-room apartment with nothing to do but look out the window at the neighbors!

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Read some good books.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I've been taking pictures so long I don't know how to read anymore.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: I'll send you some comic books.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Listen -- if you don't pull me out of this swamp of boredom -- I'll do something drastic.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I'll -- I'll get married. Then I'll never be able to go anywhere.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: It's about time you got married -- before you turn into a lonesome and bitter old man.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Can you see me -- rushing home to a hot apartment every night to listen to the automatic laundry, the electric dishwasher, the garbage disposal and a nagging wife.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Jeff -- wives don't nag anymore -- they discuss.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Yeah? Maybe in the high rent districts they discuss -- but in my neighborhood, they still nag.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Well -- you know best. Call you later, Jeff.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Next time, have some good news.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Gunnison?

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Yeah. Is that you, Jeff?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: It's me.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Something wrong?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: The word is "everything." Now what time does my plane leave Tuesday?

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Jeff --

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I don't care where it goes -- just as long as I'm on it.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Okay. Indo-China. Tuesday. We'll pick you up.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That's more like it. Goodnight, old buddy.

turns.speaker: GUNNISON
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: THORWALD
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Did you get my note?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well -- did you get it, Thorwald?

turns.speaker: THORWALD
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I'll give you a chance to find out. Meet me in the bar at the Brevoort -- and do it right away.

turns.speaker: THORWALD
turns.text: Why should I?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: For a little business meeting -- to settle the estate of your late wife.

turns.speaker: THORWALD
turns.text: I don't know what you mean.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Now stop wasting time, Thorwald, or I'll hang up and call the police.

turns.speaker: THORWALD
turns.text: I only have a hundred dollars or so.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That's a start. I'm at the Brevoort now. I'll be looking for you.

turns.speaker: THORWALD
turns.text: Can you get me that ring back?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: THORWALD
turns.text: Tell her to bring it back!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I can't. The police have it by now.

turns.speaker: THORWALD
turns.text: Then if the police get me -- you won't be around to laugh!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Readers' Digest, April, 1939.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Well, I only quote from the best.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: I predicted it.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Stella -- in economics, a kidney ailment has no relationship to the stock market. Absolutely none.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: It crashed, didn't it?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Right now I'd even welcome trouble.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: You've got a hormone deficiency.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: How can you tell that from a thermometer!

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Those sultry sun-worshipers you watch haven't raised your temperature one degree in four weeks.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: I knew it!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Don't you ever heat that stuff up.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Gives your circulation something to fight.  What kind of trouble?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Lisa Fremont.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: You must be kidding. A beautiful young woman, and you a reasonably healthy specimen of manhood.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: She expects me to marry her.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: That's normal.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I don't want to.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: That's abnormal.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I'm not ready for marriage.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Nonsense. A man is always ready for marriage -- with the right girl. And Lisa Fremont is the right girl for any man with half a brain, who can get one eye open.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: She's all right.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Behind every ridiculous statement is always hidden the true cause.  What is it? You have a fight?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Her father loading up the shotgun?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Stella!

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: It's happened before, you know! Some of the world's happiest marriage have started 'under the gun' you might say.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: She's just not the girl for me.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: She's only perfect.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Too perfect. Too beautiful, too talented, too sophisticated, too everything -- but what I want.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Is what you want something you can discuss?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: It's very simple. She belongs in that rarefied atmosphere of Park Avenue, expensive restaurants, and literary cocktail parties.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: People with sense can belong wherever they're put.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Can you see her tramping around the world with a camera bum who never has more than a week's salary in the bank?  If only she was ordinary.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: You're never going to marry?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Probably. But when I do, it'll be to someone who thinks of life as more than a new dress, a lobster dinner, and the latest scandal. I need a woman who'll go anywhere, do anything, and love it.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: The only honest thing to do is call it off. Let her look for somebody else.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: I can just hear you now. "Get out of here you perfect, wonderful woman! You're too good for me!"

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That's the hard part.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Look, Mr. Jefferies. I'm not educated. I'm not even sophisticated. But I can tell you this -- when a man and a woman see each other, and like each other -- they should come together -- wham like two taxies on Broadway. Not sit around studying each other like specimens in at bottle.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: There's an intelligent way to approach marriage.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Intelligence! Nothing has caused the human race more trouble. Modern marriage!

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: We've progressed emotionally in --

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Baloney! Once it was see somebody, get excited, get married -- Now, it's read books, fence with four syllable words, psychoanalyze each other until you can't tell a petting party from a civil service exam

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: People have different emotional levels that --

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Ask for trouble and you get it. Why there's a good boy in my neighborhood who went with a nice girl across the street for three years. Then he refused to marry her. Why? -- Because she only scored sixty-one on a Look Magazine marriage quiz!

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: When I married Myles, we were both maladjusted misfits. We still are. And we've loved every minute of it.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: That's fine, Stella. Now would you make me a sandwich?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Okay -- but I'm going to spread some common sense on the bread. Lisa Fremont's loaded to her fingertips with love for you. I'll give you two words of advice. Marry her.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: She pay you much?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: The insurance Company would be a lot happier if you slept in your bed, not the wheelchair.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: How did you know!

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Eyes bloodshot. Must have been staring out the window for hours.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: I was.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: What'll you do if one of them catches you?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Depends one which one.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Keep your mind off her.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: She's real eat, drink and be merry girl.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: And she'll end up fat, alcoholic and miserable.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Speaking of misery, Miss Lonely Hearts drank herself to sleep again. Alone.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Poor girl. Someday she'll find her happiness.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: And some man will lose his.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Isn't there anyone in the neighborhood who might cast an eye in her direction?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Well, the salesman could be available soon.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: He and his wife splitting up?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: It's hard to figure. He went out several time last night, in the rain carrying his sample case.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Isn't he a salesman?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Now what could he sell at three in the morning?

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: Flashlights. Luminous dials for watches. House numbers that light up.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: He was taking something out of the apartment. I'm certain.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: His personal effects. He's probably running away -- the coward.

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: Sometimes it's worse to stay than it is to run.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: But it takes a particularly low type of man to do it.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: What about this morning? Any developments?

turns.speaker: JEFF
turns.text: No. The shades are still drawn in their apartment.

turns.speaker: STELLA
turns.text: In this heat?  They're up now.
